Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: A serious conflict with teammates is threatening the mentee’s deliverable timeline.
Expectation2: Review and analyze legal documents and contracts
Situation2: A client has sent a standard contract for a routine service engagement that is not due back for quite some time.
Story: I stared at my inbox, the subject line from my mentor blinking at me: “Any updates on your project?” My team was in shambles—two members weren’t speaking, and our deliverable was slipping through my fingers. As a mentee, I knew I was supposed to reach out, to be honest about the chaos, but I hesitated. I didn’t want to seem incapable or unprepared. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a reminder: a client’s contract awaited my review. It was routine, not urgent, but as a lawyer, I prided myself on being thorough and timely. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down—my mentor expected transparency and initiative, my client expected diligence and reliability. My mind raced, torn between drafting an email to my mentor admitting the project was off track, or diving into the contract review to maintain my professional standards. I could feel the anxiety building, knowing I couldn’t give both roles what they demanded at the same time.
